description: Handgunner shooting attacks give a -1 Armor penalty.

One unit of Crossbowmen per full 1000 points can be replaced by Handgunners (including the 10pts extra in price) while counting for both the Crossbowmen min/max requirement and the Handgunners min/max requirement.
Frenzy:
Frenzied units must use their initiative to charge an enemy if possible and cannot use their initiative to evade.
Frenzied units cannot be driven back by shooting and do not roll for drive backs.
Frenzied units must pursue or advance where possible if victorious in combat.
Frenzied units are immune to Terror.
Pistoliers have a shooting range of 15cm.
Pistoliers can shoot 360 degrees. Measure ranges from any of the stand's edges.
Helblasters have maximum range of 30cm.
Helblasters have 8 shooting attacks when their target's range is 0cm-10cm or their target is charging.
Helblasters have 4 shooting attacks when their target's range is 10cm-20cm.
Helblasters have 2 shooting attacks when their target's range is 20cm-30cm.
Helblaster shooting attacks give a -1 Armor penalty.
When shooting with Helblasters roll to hit as normal and also count the numbers of 1s rolled:
1 or 2 1s rolled: Fizzle - Work out the attacks as usual.
3 1s rolled: Misfire - Disregard all hits this turn.

4 or more 1s rolled: Ka-boom! - The Helblaster stand is removed as a casualty. No hits are struck against the enemy unless the enemy is charging in which case 6 hits that give a -1 Armor penalty are automatically inflicted.
Cannon shooting attacks ignore enemy Armor unless the target is charging.
Cannon shooting attacks treat fortified units as being defended.
Cannon shooting attacks treat defended units as being in the open.
Bounce:

Cannonballs are assumed to hit the point on the targeted unit closest to the firing Cannon stand. In the case of units of Cannon firing at one target all hits are assumed to be at the same point on the targeted unit, the point closest to the firing unit.

The cannonball(s) Bounce forward 5cm from that point along the same line they travelled (multiple shots from the same unit follow the same line). The targeted unit suffers 2 hits from each direct cannonball hit plus 1 hit for any stand in that same unit that a cannonball bounces through. Other units (friend or foe, unengaged or engaged) suffer 1 hit for every stand a cannonball bounces through.
Hits against engaged units count towards their first combat round's result but cannot cause drive backs.
There is no Bounce if the target is charging.
Steam Tanks move up to 20cm.
Steam Tanks cannot form brigades with any units, not even other Steam Tanks.
Steam Tanks cannot be joined by characters.
Steam Tanks have a shooting range of 30cm.
Steam Tanks can shoot 360 degrees. Measure ranges from any of the stand's edges.
Steam Tank shooting attacks give a -1 Armor penalty.
Steam Tanks can shoot at charging enemies.
Steam Tanks always counts as defended.
Steam Tanks cannot be driven back or routed by shooting.
When orders given to Steam Tanks fail ignore potential blunders and instead roll a D6:
D6 roll of 1: Destroyed - Remove the Steam Tank as a casualty.

D6 roll of 2: Broken Down -The Steam Tank does not move further this turn and cannot move in future turns. Should it be obliged to move for any reason it is destroyed. Otherwise the Steam Tank can continue to shoot and fight as normal.
D6 roll of 3: Stuck - The Steam tank does not move further this turn. It cannot shoot this turn. Otherwise it is unaffected and can move in future turns as normal.

D6 roll of 4: Commander Slain - The Steam Tank does not move further this turn. It can move in future turns but gets a -1 Command penalty for the rest of the battle. The Steam Tank can shoot as normal.
D6 roll of 5: Momentary Halt - The Steam Tank cannot move further this turn but is otherwise unaffected.
D6 roll of 6: Steam Overload - The Steam Tank cannot move further this turn but can shoot with double the usual number of Attacks (6).
SPELLS:
-- Ball of Flame --
To cast: 5+
Range: 30cm
To cast: 5+
Draw a line 30cm long from the caster's stand in any direction. The line stops short if it touches terrain that would normally stop a missile shot.
All units (friend and foe) under the line take 3 shooting attacks.
Both enemy and friendly units that are unengaged require drive back rolls if they take hits.
Hits against engaged units count towards their first combat round's result but cannot cause drive backs.
-- Voice of Command --
To cast: 5+
Range: 30cm
Only unengaged friendly units can be targeted.
The targeted unit does not have to be visible to the caster.
The targeted unit can make a move as if it had received an order in the Command phase.
Supporting charges cannot be made to support a charge made with this move.
Characters in the targeted unit do not move along with it.
-- Weird Enchantment --
To cast: 4+
Range: 30cm
Only unengaged enemy units can be targeted.
The targeted unit does not have to be visible to the caster.
This spell lasts until the end of the opposing player's next turn.
The targeted unit havles its move allowance for the duration of its next Command phase.
The targeted unit treats all of its enemies as causing Terror even if the targeted unit is otherwise immune to Terror. Undead and Demons are the only exceptions; they are still immune to Terror.
If the targeted unit causes Terror it ceases to do so.
-- Teleport --
To cast: 2+
Range: N/A
The caster moves to a new position anywhere on the table.
The caster is permitted to leave units with the Teleport spell even if their unit is in combat.
A second spell can be cast immediately after casting Teleport. The second spell cannot be another Teleport spell.

Undead units do not get the -1 Command penalty for enemy within 20cm.

SPELLS:
-- Raise Dead --
To cast: 5+
Range: 30cm
Only a combat engagement can be targeted.
Neither unit in the targeted combat engagement has to be visible to the caster.
A single combat engagement can only be affected once by this spell in any turn.
A Skeleton unit of three stands is created and placed so that it can either fight in the combat engagement (if there is room) or support a friendly unit that is already engaged.
If there is insufficient room for the raised unit to fit either in the combat engagement or in support then the spell cannot be cast.
Raised units do not count as having charged the turn they are raised.
Raised units do not count toward their army's break value.
Raised units are not worth any victory points.
-- Touch of Death --
To cast: 4+
Range: Touching
The caster must be in a unit that is in combat to use this spell.
Only units engaged with the caster's unit can be targeted.
The targeted unit takes 3 attacks with hits counting towards the first combat round's result.
-- Doom and Despair --
To cast: 4+
Range: 60cm
The targeted unit does not have to be visible to the caster.
This spell lasts until the end of the opposing player's next turn.
The targeted unit does not have to be visible to the caster.
The targeted unit cannot charge, pursue or advance. Even if the unit is otherwise obliged to charge, pursue or advance it cannot do so. Not even Undead are immmune.
-- Death Bolt --
To cast: 5+
Range: 30cm
Only unengaged enemy units that are visible to the caster can be targeted.
The targeted unit takes 3 shooting attacks with no armor saves.
If Ogres can use their initiative to charge an enemy unit of humans (not elves or dwarfs) at the start of the Command phase then they must do so.
When issuing an order to Trolls or to a brigade that contains Trolls there is a -1 Command penalty.

Trolls can regenerate wounds. In each round of combat after whole stands have been removed Trolls automatically regenerate 1 outstanding hit. If no hits are left over after removing whole stands then regeneration has no effect. Regenerated hits still count towards the combat result for the round.
Harpies are based facing the long edge of the base in the same way as infantry rather than the short edge like most monsters.
Harpies can fly.
Harpy units cannot be joined by characters.
Dragon Ogres are immune to Terror

Chaos Spawn can be included as a bonus to the size of a brigade up to a maximum of one Spawn per non-Spawn unit. For example, 4 Chaos Warriors plus 4 Spawn counts as a brigade of 4 units; the 4 Spawn do not count towards the size of the brigade. Where several Spawn are brigaded with fewer non-Spawn units then only the additional Spawn count towards the size of the brigade. For example, 2 Chaos Warriors and 4 Spawn count as 4 units; 2 Spawn are included "for free."
Chaos Spawn cannot be given orders in the Command phase unless they are part of a brigade that includes at least one unit other than Spawn but can act on their initiative as normal.
Chaos Spawn cause Terror.
Chaos Spawn have a shooting range of 15cm.
Chaos Spawn can shoot 360 degrees. Measure the range from any of the stand's edges.
SPELLS:
-- Boon of Chaos --
To cast: 4+
Range: N/A
The caster must be in a unit that is in combat to use this spell.
Only the caster's own unit can be targeted.
This spell lasts for the duration of the current turn's Combat phase.
All stands in the unit get a +1 Attacks bonus except that only one character stand gets this bonus (whichever character is fighting).
-- Anger of the Gods --
To cast: 4+
Range: 30cm
Only the caster themself can be targeted.
This spell lasts until the end of the opposing player's next turn.
All enemy units (within range) suffer a -1 Command penalty.
-- Rage of Chaos --
To cast 4+
Range: 30cm
Only friendly units that are engaged in combat can be targeted.
The targeted unit does not have to be visible to the caster.
This spell lasts for the duration of the current turn's Combat phase.
The targeted unit gets a number of extra Attacks that is determined in the following way:
Roll 1 D6 at a time and add each result together.
This rolling may be stopped voluntarily at any time.
The rolling automatically stops when a number that has already been rolled is rolled a second time.
The rolling automatiicaly stopps when the number of rolls equals the number of stands in the targeted unit.
If rolling was stopped without having rolled same number twice then the total value of the rolls is the Attacks bonus the targeted unit gets that round.
If rolling was stopped as a result of rolling the same number twice then the total value of the rolls is the number of attacks made by the targeted unit against itself.
-- Curse of Chaos --
To cast: 5+
Range: 30cm
Only unengaged enemy units that are visible to the caster can be targeted.
The targeted unit takes 3 shooting attacks with no armor saves.
Goblins have a shooting range of 15cm.
When issuing an order to Trolls or brigade that contains Trolls there is a -1 Command penalty.

Trolls can regenerate wounds. In each round of combat after whole stands have been removed Trolls automatically regenerate 1 outstanding hit. If no hits are left over after removing whole stands then regeneration has no effect. Regenerated hits still count towards the combat result for the round.
If Ogres can use their initiative to charge an enemy unit of humans (not elves or dwarfs) at the start of the Command phase then they must do so.

Giants can only form brigades with other Giants.
Giants cause Terror.

Giants that have accumulated 4-7 hits by the end of the Shooting phase or Combat phase and are no longer engaged in combat they are considered badly hurt. Their accumulated hits are discounted, and their Attacks and Hits values are halved for the rest of the battle (to 4 Attacks and 4 Hits).
When orders given to Giants fail ignore potential blunders and instead roll a D6 (for brigades of Giants roll once for the brigade):
D6 roll of 1: The Giant(s) do not move or fight this turn.

D6 roll of 2: The Giant(s) move their full move directly towards the nearest table edge. If they move into another unit, friend or foe, they attack it. If victorious in combat the Giant(s) hold their ground.

D6 roll of 3: The Giant(s) pick up whatever is handy and throw it at the closest unit, friend or foe, that they can see. These objects travel 5xD6cm and strike with 3 Attacks if they reaches the target.

D6 roll of 4: The Giant(s) move their full move in the direction they are already facing. If they reach an enemy unit they attack as normal. If they reach a friendly unit they walk through them if there is room and sufficient move. If they reach a friendly unit and do not have sufficient move or enough room to go all the way through then they halt on contact. A friendly unit that is walked through or contacted in this way becomes Confused for the remainder of the Command phase.

D6 roll of 5: The Giant(s) move their full move towards the nearest enemy unit. If they reach them they attack as normal. If friends are in the way they will walk through them causing Confusion as described above.
D6 roll of 6: The Giant(s) move double their normal full move towards the nearest enemy unit. If they reach an enemy unit they attack and double their Attacks value in the first round of combat.
Rock Lobber shooting attacks ignore enemy Armor.
Rock Lobbers cannot shoot at charging units.

Shooting Blind: If there are no targets in sight Rock Lobbers can instead shoot at the nearest enemy unit in range that they cannot see. When Shooting Blind Rock Lobbers always hit on 6+ whether the target is in the open, defended or even fortified.

-- Storm of Stone --
To cast: 6+
Range: 30cm
All enemy units (in range) take D3 attacks each. Roll to determine the number of attacks for each unit separately.
Hits from this spell cannot cause drive backs.

All friendly units (in range) and characters that have joined them get 1 extra attack; any one stand in the unit can be given the unit's extra attack.

Troll Slayers get a +1 Attacks bonus when fighting against a monster stand.

Troll Slayer units earn victory points differently than other units. If a Troll Slayer unit has any stands remaining at the end of the battle then the full points value of the unit is awarded to the opposing side as victory points. It does not matter if the unit has 3, 2 or 1 stand remaining; if there are any stands left at all the enemy gets the full victory points. If a Troll Slayer unit is destroyed no victory points are scored by either side. Slayer units that have been destroyed still count towards the Dwarf army's losses for purposes of calculating withdrawal.

Flame Cannon have 2D6 Attacks. If a double is rolled then something has gone wrong. Roll 2D6:
Roll of double-1: The Flame Cannon explodes and is destroyed. No hits are caused.
Roll of double-2: The Flame Cannon inflicts 2D6+4 hits on the target before it explodes and is destroyed.\n
Roll of double-3: The Flame Cannon inflicts 6 hits on the target this turn but has 1D6 Attacks instead of 2D6 for the rest of the battle.
Roll of double-4: The Flame Cannon does not shoot this turn but is otherwise unaffected.
Roll of double-5: The Flame Cannon inflicts 10 hits on the target and is otherwise unaffected.
Roll of double-6: The Flame Cannon inflicts D6+12 hits on the target and is otherwise unaffected.

Gutter Runners do not have to be deployed before the battle and can instead Ambush:

To Ambush with a unit of Gutter Runners the Skaven player nominates the point where they want the Gutter Runners to appear and issues a deployment order from any friendly character anywhere on the battlefield (apply the modifiers for distance and proximity of enemy but not for dense terrain).
The nominated point for an Ambush must be either within dense terrain or on any battlefield edge other than the edge of the enemy army's deployment zone.

If the deployment order succeeds the unit Ambushes; place one stand of the unit on the nominated spot and arrange the rest into formation around it. No stand can be placed in contact with an enemy unit.
If the deployment order fails the unit does not Ambush that turn; they can attempt to Ambush again in a subsequent turn at the same or a different place.

After a unit Ambushes successfully orders can be given to it by the same character that gave the deployment order if the unit is within the character's normal command range. The Ambush counts as the Ambushing unit's first order.
In the turn a unit of Gutter Runners Ambushes it cannot form brigades with any other units.

Units that are touching a unit that takes casualties from a Warp Lightning Cannon must also roll a D6 immediately and on a roll of 6 become confused. This includes Skaven units touching the Warp Lightning Cannon when it inflicts casualties on itself.

Elephants cause Terror.
If an Elephant unit would otherwise become confused for any reason then it will stampede instead. The Confusion rules do not apply.
Stampeding elephants automatically cease to stampede at the end of their Command phase.
Stampeding Elephants cannot be given orders or use initiative. Instead roll a D6 at the start of the Command phase before moving anything else on initiative:

D6 roll of 1 or 2: The Elephant moves as far as possible toward the nearest enemy unit. If the Elephants contacts the enemy they count as charging. If the elephant contacts a friendly unit it counts as moving into friends (see below).

D6 roll of 3 or 4: The Elephant moves as far as possible directly away from the nearest enemy unit. If the elephant contacts another enemy unit it counts as charging (see above). If the elephant contacts a friendly unit it counts as moving into friends (see below).
D6 roll of 5: The Elephant moves as far as possible toward the nearest friendly unit. If the stampeding elephants contact the friendly unit they automatically count as charging.
D6 roll of 6: The Elephant moves as far as possible directly away from the nearest friendly unit. If the elephant contacts an enemy or friendly unit it counts as charging (see above).

A Stampeding Elephant unit that charges into an enemy or friendly unit fights in the Combat phase in the same way as a regular charging unit. The stampeding Elephant counts as "enemies" for the duration of the combat and therefore continue to cause Terror in opponents regardless of which side they are on. The Elephants count as charging in the first round. If the Elephants win a combat round then they must pursue if possible and will continue to do so each round. Should their opponents be destroyed they will not advance but will halt without reforming.

Stampeding Elephants might conceivably move into a unit, therefore initiating combat, but be unable to form a battleline because they have insufficient move distance. In the case of stampeding Elephants the combat is still fought and the Elephants still count as charging. It is up to the player whether they move the elephants the extra distance required to make a battleline or simply fight with the elephants in an irregular formation.

When orders given to Giants fail ignore potential blunders and instead roll a D6 (for brigades of Giants roll once for the brigade):
D6 roll of 1: The Giant(s) do not move or fight this turn.

D6 roll of 2: The Giant(s) move their full move directly towards the nearest table edge. If they move into another unit, friend or foe, they attack it. If victorious in combat the Giant(s) hold their ground.

D6 roll of 3: The Giant(s) pick up whatever is handy and throw it at the closest unit, friend or foe, that they can see. These objects travel 5xD6cm and strike with 3 Attacks if they reaches the target.

D6 roll of 4: The Giant(s) move their full move in the direction they are already facing. If they reach an enemy unit they attack as normal. If they reach a friendly unit they walk through them if there is room and sufficient move. If they reach a friendly unit and do not have sufficient move or enough room to go all the way through then they halt on contact. A friendly unit that is walked through or contacted in this way becomes Confused for the remainder of the Command phase.

D6 roll of 5: The Giant(s) move their full move towards the nearest enemy unit. If they reach them they attack as normal. If friends are in the way they will walk through them causing Confusion as described above.
D6 roll of 6: The Giant(s) move double their normal full move towards the nearest enemy unit. If they reach an enemy unit they attack and double their Attacks value in the first round of combat.

To cast: 6+
Range: 60cm
Only a forest can be targeted.
All enemy units within 10cm of the targeted forest take 3 shooting attacks with no armor saves that cannot cause drive backs.
Hits against engaged units count towards their first combat round's result.
Up to half the total number of both Beastherd and Herdkin units (rounded down) can Ambush instead of deploying before the battle:
Beastherds and Herdkin that Ambush must do so in groups of up to four units. Herdkin units cannot outnumber Beastherd units in these groups.

To Ambush with a group of Beastherd and Herdkin units the Beastmen player nominates the point where they want the group to appear and issues a deployment order from any friendly character anywhere on the battlefield (apply the modifiers for proximity of enemy but not for distance and dense terrain).

The nominated point for an Ambush must be either within a terrain feature or on any battlefield edge other than the edge of the enemy army's deployment zone. If the terrain feature is dense terrain then every unit in the Ambushing group must be placed at least partially within the terrain feature.

If the deployment order succeeds the group Ambushes; place one stand of one unit in the group on the nominated spot and arrange the remaining stands into formation around it. Then place the remaining units of the ambushing group next to each so that very unit is touching at least one stand of another unit from that Ambushing group. No stand can be placed in contact with an enemy unit.
If the deployment order fails the group does not Ambush that turn; they can attempt to Ambush again in a subsequent turn at the same or a different place.

After a unit or group Ambushes successfully orders can be given to them by the same character that gave the deployment order if the group is within the character's normal command range. The Ambush counts as the Ambushing unit's first order.
A group of Beastherd and Herdkin units that has just Ambushed is ordered together as a brigade.
Beastherd and Herdkin units cannot form brigades with other types of units the turn they Ambush.

Frenzy:
Frenzied units must use their initiative to charge an enemy if possible and cannot use their initiative to evade.
Frenzied units cannot be driven back by shooting and do not roll for drive backs.
Frenzied units must pursue or advance where possible if victorious in combat.
Frenzied units are immune to Terror.
Centigors cannot provide or receive support.
Despite being infantry Centigors can pursue any type of retreating enemy.
Dragon Ogres are immune to Terror.

Chaos Spawn can be included as a bonus to the size of a brigade up to a maximum of one Spawn per non-Spawn unit. For example, 4 Chaos Warriors plus 4 Spawn counts as a brigade of 4 units; the 4 Spawn do not count towards the size of the brigade. Where several Spawn are brigaded with fewer non-Spawn units then only the additional Spawn count towards the size of the brigade. For example, 2 Chaos Warriors and 4 Spawn count as 4 units; 2 Spawn are included "for free."
Chaos Spawn cannot be given orders in the Command phase unless they are part of a brigade that includes at least one unit other than Spawn but can act on their initiative as normal.
Chaos Spawn cause Terror.
Chaos Spawn have a shooting range of 15cm.
Chaos Spawn can shoot 360 degrees. Measure the range from any of the stand's edges.
Dragon Ogre Shaggoths cannot form brigades with other units, not even with other Dragon Ogre Shaggoths.
Dragon Ogre Shaggoths cause Terror.

Dragon Ogre Shaggoths that have accumulated 5-7 hits by the end of the Shooting phase or Combat phase and are no longer engaged in combat they are considered badly hurt. Their accumulated hits are discounted, and their Attacks and Hits values are halved for the rest of the battle (to 4 Attacks and 4 Hits).
When Doombulls join Beastherd, Herdkin and Bestigor units those units get Frenzy:
Frenzied units must use their initiative to charge an enemy if possible and cannot use their initiative to evade.
Frenzied units cannot be driven back by shooting and do not roll for drive backs.
Frenzied units must pursue or advance where possible if victorious in combat.
Frenzied units are immune to Terror.

Ulfwerener are based facing the short edge of the base in the same way as cavalry rather than the long edge like most infantry.

Ulfwerener get a +1 Attacks bonus when charging a unit in the open in the same way as chariots and monsters.
Ulfwerener stands cannot support or be supported.
Ulfwerener can only be joined by charcters with Were Kin.
Ulfwerener cannot have magic items.
Giants can only form brigades with other Giants.
Giants cause Terror.

Giants that have accumulated 4-7 hits by the end of the Shooting phase or Combat phase and are no longer engaged in combat they are considered badly hurt. Their accumulated hits are discounted, and their Attacks and Hits values are halved for the rest of the battle (to 4 Attacks and 4 Hits).
When orders given to Giants fail ignore potential blunders and instead roll a D6 (for brigades of Giants roll once for the brigade):
D6 roll of 1: The Giant(s) do not move or fight this turn.

D6 roll of 2: The Giant(s) move their full move directly towards the nearest table edge. If they move into another unit, friend or foe, they attack it. If victorious in combat the Giant(s) hold their ground.

D6 roll of 3: The Giant(s) pick up whatever is handy and throw it at the closest unit, friend or foe, that they can see. These objects travel 5xD6cm and strike with 3 Attacks if they reaches the target.
The Grey Seer can use Skaven magic in the same manner as a Warlock.
Under the Lash: Skaven characters have a Command range of 20cm.
SPELLS:
-- Skitterleap --

D6 roll of 4: The Giant(s) move their full move in the direction they are already facing. If they reach an enemy unit they attack as normal. If they reach a friendly unit they walk through them if there is room and sufficient move. If they reach a friendly unit and do not have sufficient move or enough room to go all the way through then they halt on contact. A friendly unit that is walked through or contacted in this way becomes Confused for the remainder of the Command phase.

D6 roll of 5: The Giant(s) move their full move towards the nearest enemy unit. If they reach them they attack as normal. If friends are in the way they will walk through them causing Confusion as described above.
D6 roll of 6: The Giant(s) move double their normal full move towards the nearest enemy unit. If they reach an enemy unit they attack and double their Attacks value in the first round of combat.
Mammoths must be mounted on stands/bases that are 40mm wide and 60mm deep.
Mammoths cause Terror.

Mammoths that have accumulated 6-9 hits by the end of the Shooting phase or Combat phase and are no longer engaged in combat they are considered badly hurt. Their accumulated hits are discounted, and their Attacks and Hits values are halved for the rest of the battle (to 4 Attacks and 5 Hits).
Mammoths can attack units on ramparts in the same matter as Giants.
Mammoths can batter a wall section or gateway in the same matter as Battering Rams.
Mammoths can function as Siege Towers with the exception that enemies behind walls count as defended rather than in the open. When functioning as Siege Towers Mammoths cannot attack or batter walls.
A Norse army, no matter how large, can have no more than one unit of Valkyries.
Valkries can fly.
Valkyries cannot be deployed before the game as normal and must instead Ambush:

To Ambush with a unit of Valkyries the Norse player nominates the point where they want the Valkyries to appear and issues a deployment order from a Shaman anywhere on the battlefield that has the Horn of Resounding (apply the modifiers for distance and proximity of enemy but not for dense terrain).
The nominated point for an Ambush must be either within dense terrain or on any battlefield edge other than the edge of the enemy army's deployment zone.

If the deployment order succeeds the unit Ambushes; place one stand of the unit on the nominated spot and arrange the rest into formation around it. No stand can be placed in contact with an enemy unit.
If the deployment order fails the unit does not Ambush that turn; they can attempt to Ambush again in a subsequent turn at the same or a different place.

After a unit Ambushes successfully orders can be given to it by the same character that gave the deployment order if the unit is within the character's normal command range. The Ambush counts as the Ambushing unit's first order.
In the turn a unit of Valkyries Ambushes it cannot form brigades with any other units.
If the Shaman with the Horn of Resounding dies then Valkyries can Home Back to and be commanded by the General but with a -2 Command penalty.

Roll 1 D6 at a time and add each result together.

Before deploying armies the Wood Elf player may decide to place additional forest(s) instead of fielding one of their Wardancer units (assuming there is one in the list).
